title: Ainsworth urges shareholders to keep the faith
text:
Ainsworth Game Technology has urged shareholders to keep faith in the company after a year in which profit dove $20 million and share prices plunged 30 per cent.

Founded by Rich Lister and gambling baron Len Ainsworth in 1995, the poker machine company had a horror 2019 financial year as its domestic business weakened amid harsh global conditions.

Ainsworth's result was driven by a poor performance in Australia. Peter Braig

After-tax profits were down to $10.9 million during the 2019 period, compared to $31.9 million in the 2018 financial year. Investors sent the share price spiralling from $1.01 to 67¢ in the same period, though this has since recovered to 82¢.

"Domestic sales were poor for the year," said chief executive Lawrence Levy. "In Latin America, political elections and the introduction of new gaming taxes adversely affected local economies and industry spend ... In our Rest of the World segment, revenues fell by 35 per cent to $12 million."

However, Mr Levy was confident that Ainsworth could arrest the decline in the domestic business as it entered a product transition period.
